Please help improve this article by introducing more precise citations. *(October 2023)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Charles Andrew Dyce** (1816–1853) was born in St Nicholas, [Aberdeen](/wiki/Aberdeen), Scotland to parents William Dyce and Margaret Chalmers who were married on 8 Feb 1798. Charles is also the younger brother of [William Dyce](/wiki/William_Dyce) (1806–1864), a renowned Scottish artist and a [Royal Academician](/wiki/Royal_Academician). He arrived in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) from [India](/wiki/India) in 1842 and was a merchant. In his stay in Singapore, Charles took on positions as First Secretary of the [Singapore Sporting Club](/wiki/Singapore_Sporting_Club), an amateur thespian and, in 1847, [High Sheriff](/wiki/High_Sheriff) for the [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements) of Singapore, [Malacca](/wiki/Malacca) and [Penang](/wiki/Penang). He met and married Eliza Hyde in 1845 in Singapore and had a son. They left for [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta) together with him. Charles also produced many [sepia](/wiki/Sepia_tone) and [watercolor paintings](/wiki/Watercolor_painting) of scenes and landscapes in the Southeast Asian region. These works of art now form *The Charles Dyce Collection* found in the South & Southeast Asian Gallery of the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) (NUS) Museum. ## Bibliography ### Papers - Widodo, Johannes (2004), *Charles Andrew Dyce in Indonesia (1845) - The Journey through Riau to Batavia and through the old Great Western Road to Buitenzorg* in Lim, Irene (2004). *Sketching the Straits: a compilation of the lecture series of Charles Dyce collection*.
